sen.j: 系譜の直系のみを示せば、「凡牟都和希王 ― 若野毛二俣王 ― 大郎子（意富富等王） ― 乎非王 ― 斯王 ― 乎富等大公王」となる。
sen.e: If we trace only the direct lines of genealogy for Prince Oi from the Joguki, it could be written this way: "Homutawake no Miko (凡牟都和希王) –Wakanuke futamata no Miko (若野毛二俣王) – Oiratsuko (大郎子) [Ohodo no Okimi (意富富等王)] – Oi no Okimi (乎非王) – Ushi no Okimi (斯王) – Odo no Okimi (乎富等大公王)."

sen.j: それぞれ凡牟都和希（ほむたわけ）王は応神天皇、若野毛二俣（わかぬけふたまた）王は稚野毛二派皇子、大郎子は意富富杼王、 斯（うし）王は彦主人王、乎富等（おおど）大公王は継体天皇に比定され得る。
sen.e: Each of these names can be identified as follows: 'Homutawake no Miko' was the Emperor Ojin; 'Wakanuke futamata no Miko' was 'Wakanoke futamata no Miko'; Oiratsuko was 'Ohodo no Okimi'; 'Ushi no Okimi' was 'Hikoushio' (also pronounced 'Hikousi no Okimi') and 'Odo no Okimi' was the Emperor Keitai.

sen.j: 近年の研究によれば、この6代から若野毛二俣王と大郎子を除いた「応神 ― 乎非 ― 斯 ― 継体」が本来の系譜とされている（川口勝康氏）。
sen.e: However, according to recent historical research and studies, the original genealogy might be written like this: "the Emperor Ojin – Oi no Okimi - Ushi no Okimi – the Emperor Keitai" which extended into two generations, was eliminated from the six generations of the genealogy as described in the Joguki: 'Wakanuke futamata no Miko' and 'Oiratsuko' (Mr. Katsuyasu KAWAGUCHI).

sen.e: As to "Shi (or Oi) no Okimi (私斐王)" in those historical books, there were no previous examples of ancient writers or editors using "Shi (私)" for Manyogana (early Japanese syllabify composed of Chinese characters then used phonetically); so historians and other scholars would be able to conclude that the original writing was written in this way "Oi no Okimi (弘斐王)" and "Shi (or Oi) no Okimi (私斐王)" was the transcription mistake.
